pageSubtitle: v5.0 Per-Sector Calibrated Model — 16 features, temporal validation, PU-learning

overview.description: RUBLI v5.0 scores every contract with a calibrated corruption probability using per-sector logistic regression trained on 15 documented cases. Scores are honest out-of-sample estimates — the model was trained on contracts through 2020 and tested on 2021+.

riskLevels.title: Risk Levels
riskLevels.disclaimer: Risk scores are calibrated probabilities with 95% confidence intervals. A high score indicates statistical anomaly consistent with corruption patterns — it does not constitute proof.

coefficients.title: v5.0 Global Model Coefficients
coefficients.subtitle: 16 z-score features ranked by absolute coefficient magnitude. Positive = increases risk; negative = decreases risk.

keyFindings.title: What the Model Learned
keyFindings.concentrationDetail: Vendor concentration, price volatility, and win rate are the top 3 predictors. These reflect Mexico's documented corruption pattern: large vendors capturing institutional monopolies.
keyFindings.directAwardDetail: In v4.0, the direct_award coefficient was -0.197 (counterintuitive). With diversified ground truth and new features in v5.0, it correctly flipped to +0.182.
keyFindings.singleBidWeak: Single bidding is a weak signal
keyFindings.singleBidDetail: Despite being the #1 indicator in European datasets, single bidding has a near-zero coefficient in Mexico. This reflects the 70% direct award rate — competitive procedures are rare, so single bids carry less information.
keyFindings.coBiddingZeroDetail: Regularized to exactly 0.000 in all models. The training cases involve concentration, not collusion rings.

validation.title: Ground Truth Validation
validation.description: Detection rates on 15 documented corruption cases (26,582 contracts from 27 matched vendors).
validation.footnote: * Case 9 shares vendors with Case 5 (Odebrecht). Documented for reference.

statisticalMethods.zScoreDesc: Each feature is standardized relative to its sector and year baseline. A direct award in Defensa (80% are direct) is less suspicious than in Educación (50% are direct). Z-scores capture this context.
statisticalMethods.mahalanobisDesc: Measures how unusual a contract's feature vector is in multidimensional space. Replaces the 5 hardcoded interaction pairs from v3.3 with a full covariance matrix that captures all pairwise relationships.
statisticalMethods.perSectorDesc: v5.0 trains 12 dedicated models (one per sector) plus a global fallback. Corruption patterns differ by sector — Energía is driven by industry mismatch, while Agricultura is driven by vendor concentration (+1.82).
statisticalMethods.perSectorFormula: P(corrupt|z) = σ(β₀ + βᵀz) / c, where c = 0.887 (PU correction)

v33.title: Previous Model: v3.3 (Weighted Checklist)
v33.description: v3.3 used 8 expert-weighted factors based on IMF CRI methodology. Preserved in risk_score_v3 column for comparison.

dataSources.title: Data Sources — COMPRANET
dataSources.description: Data quality varies significantly by period. Risk scores for 2002–2010 are directional estimates, not precise probabilities.

groundTruth.pageSubtitle: Documented corruption cases validate the risk detection model
groundTruth.callout: This page measures RUBLI's detection capability against real, documented Mexican procurement corruption cases. Each case was independently investigated by journalists, auditors, or prosecutors. Our model never saw these labels during training — the detection rates shown here represent genuine out-of-sample predictive performance.
